Nov 6, 2021

Parliament Calendar: calculating scrutiny periods

Nov 6, 2021

Should you ever wish to calculate the scrutiny period in the UK Parliament for legislative reform orders, drafts under the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018, … perhaps even treaty objection periods … you might refer to parliament-calendar.herokuapp.com.

You should not rely on this service as legal or professional advice, or as a substitute for it. We do not accept any liability whatsoever for any errors, omissions or misstatements contained herein. You should consult a suitably qualified professional if you require specific advice or information.

The assumptions made in interpreting legislation which form the basis of our calculations are documented at https://parliament-calendar.herokuapp.com/meta/comments.

Footpath between Kathleen Road and Dorothy Road, Battersea. September 2017.

Sep 24, 2018

The doorway of Battersea reference library. September 2017. “Dated 1924. Designed by Henry Hyams. Small building with 3 aisles divided by cast iron columns, the central aisle with glazed barrel-vault. Gallery with ornamented, oak-panelled front. Fore building to street of one and two low storeys. Picturesque design in ‘Arts and Crafts’ manner. Red brick dressed with Portland stone and hipped, tiled roofs. Arched entrance with carved decoration. Railings, lanterns, clock-turret, oak doors etc.” Historic England

An example of a botanical ‘sport’, or lusus: “a part of a plant that shows morphological differences from the rest of the plant. Sports may differ by foliage shape or color, flowers, or branch structure.” Wikipedia

Apr 7, 2018

In 1780 Captain James Cook died “an inglorious death off Hawaii.” Elizabeth Cook, his wife, was 38, with three remaining children of six. (Drowning, robbery, fever). Much more from Gillian Tindall.

Apr 7, 2018

I’m saying goodbye to a selection of podcasts - and welcoming in a new batch. I’m still looking for a podcast directory that unearths the unknowns. Also: Jeremy Keith’s Huffduffer is still excellent and still hugely underrated. Check out the wonderfully comprehensive API.

Apr 2, 2018

Scratching around in Max from Cycling ‘74. People used to write wikis, then Twitter clients. Now I’m trying to put together the barest skeleton of a micro.blog client a day after paying for a licence. It … actually works. I am delighted. Time to go for a walk.

Listening to Cerys Matthews on the psalms - watching Lachlan Goudie, “Painting the Holy Land”. Though I am without faith, both very good. It does still feel like the radio expects I can think more than television ever does.

Mar 31, 2018

So is Hamlet’s uncle afraid of him? Does he care for him? Does he think Hamlet knows …? Does Hamlet really want to kill himself? Why would he? I thought he wanted to revenge his father? And is he only afraid of killing himself because he’s heard from his father’s ghost of hell?

Mar 31, 2018

Watching the Almeida production of Hamlet. It’s a bit stagey, I think. Difficult to translate from the small stage to the small screen. What’s stronger, Hamlet’s love for his father, or disgust at his mother’s apparently too-swift remarriage?

Mar 31, 2018
Mar 31, 2018
Mar 30, 2018

If Tumblr had a $5/month plan, I’d use it. If Twitter had a $5/month plan, I’d use it. If Anchor had a $5/month plan, I’d use it. If Zapier had a $5/month plan, I’d use it. If Fireside had a $5/month plan, I’d use it. Turns out Micro.blog does have a $5/month plan - and I use it.

Mar 30, 2018

If you’re upgrading, you should check out Ryan Christoffel’s writeup of iOS 11.3 at MacStories. When Apple’s release notes are too cursory and dry - when many sites just republish the barest bullet-points - MacStories is approachable and comprehensive writing.

Mar 30, 2018

Listening to: the history of basketball, from Scott Cooper. The very early history reminds me of real tennis and fives. Scott reads all the original rules of the game and keeps up a good clip to keep it under 20 minutes. One for the hardcore fans, I think.

Thinking about how people used to listen to the wireless. They could see each other’s faces. A necessarily communal experience. Now our screens are personally owned, personally consumed. Laptops are marketed on this basis too. Is there still any communal media remaining?

Oct 24, 2017

A Flex by Filofax plain notebook, grey, crudely inked in red biro; Apple’s iPhone 7 Plus, in a wooden cradle, playing a podcast; a French textbook, no - German, surely; over that, open to three panes of A4, the daily listings for the Festival Hall for next month; over that, the plastic safety glasses I use while handling an axe; two tulip bulbs; a wooden bowl of fruit, most of which is lightly decayed; a vase I may have got at Lewes; a folded paper map; a small stack of material posted, including something that seems uncommonly like a cheque book; my most-recent favourite bag, a black Porter, open; one toothbrush in a paired package; at least two receipts, screwed up in order to be burned later; a Waitrose bag; two Duracell AA battery packs; the running order for the Wigmore Hall for this month and the month before; under there several Sharpie markers; a small pad of large Post-It notes; a small Hasani mug, from which I have drunk cocoa, only cocoa powder and milk; back here to a MacBook with a notorious keyboard, nothing sticks yet, but some keys fail to register now and then. At the other end of the table: a large chili plant; an aloe, doing quite well; some sort of lily; a pink-purple orchid; several emptied glass containers; a crude clay pot, unvarnished; unlit candles; pens; papers; a flint; pair of scissors; soft-back notebooks.

People barely recognise themselves, barely know themselves. What they mean to others, what they can be - not for themselves, but for anyone else. And sometimes it’s only a word away. I must find a way of recognising that and of celebrating it.

“I was living in a squat, in Covent Garden … The roof had burned off in a fire, and during the winter there was three feet of snow in the toilet.” Neville Brody

Jul 7, 2017

Some time ago I wrote something like story, called The Island - it’s on GitHub. I’m thinking of rewriting it in Twine.

Jul 7, 2017

“You go from being hot to old and out-of-action in a flash. But you have to stay old for about a decade in order to become iconic.” Chi Modu

Jul 7, 2017
Jul 6, 2017

London. Eating a bourek, by a reproduction of the Golden Hinde, in which a woman sings in a language I can’t quite place, to the backing of a little band high up on the poop. Her voice runs high up the walls. Even the tourists stop. A security guard in a nearby office dances.

Jun 28, 2017

I was thinking about people who “are artists”, today. The way is, to “be an artist”. I think I have an abiding horror of: lottery results, generated conflict, superstitions, retreats into anti-progressive-ness. If we can forge ahead, why would we not. However wide the road.

“Rose gold resin relentlessly drips down the walls” - a photo by Patricia Chang in an article by Stefanie Tuder on opening a restaurant in San Francisco.

Jun 27, 2017

“During my first year, Paul used to go to the art class during free periods and sit opposite me. I would flick pieces of paper at him.” Ozzie Yue

Jun 27, 2017

I am enjoying, again, the sainted Jeremy Brett in ‘The Man With The Twisted Lip’. What an extraordinary production: the pacing, the music. The use of mirrors, throughout the series, matched here with water-as-transformation. The music, water, mirrors. The flow of it all. Lovely.

Jun 27, 2017

“We can see no earthly reason for anyone to ever quit Flickr, but if you want to break our hearts and leave, we’ll show you how to delete your Flickr account.” Flickr, Yahoo, Verizon Yeah well. Soon.

Jun 26, 2017

I shifted from the World Service, to Radio 4, to Radio 3 - then to podcasts. I tried Radio 4 again recently. It’s like no time has passed at all. Why not? What happened? Why did nothing change? What would a rebooted Radio 4 sound like?

“A website should not fight the browser. Let the browser provide the chrome, and simply provide the content.” John Gruber

Jun 20, 2017

Wonderful though Frontier was, I think Brent Simmons should instead think about developing Pharo. It’s on a virtual machine, the code is built into the environment, the tooling is pretty amazing, it has addressable structures that feel like tables to me and it’s open source.

Jun 19, 2017

“As Marina Abramović said: a good artist has one great idea; a genius has two.” Tommy Cash

Jun 19, 2017

I’ve decided to let my Flickr Pro account end in September 2017. I’ve been a Flickr user for many years - and enjoyed it, for the most part. But it really doesn’t feel like it used to. I joined for the people first, rather than the photos. Most of the people I knew have gone.

Jun 19, 2017

Steve Rose reviews ‘Hampstead’: “‘It’s never too late to change your life,’ ran that movie’s tagline. Judi Dench probably has a tattoo of that.”

Jun 19, 2017

“Graham says he used to have ‘nice hairy legs’ - after he got Cotard’s [syndrome], all the hairs fell out. ‘I looked like a plucked chicken! Saves shaving them I suppose.'” Helen Thompson

Jun 19, 2017

It’s too warm to wear headphones. The river is full, tipped up to meet the heavy trees. Between the rails, birds call frantically. Dust on leaves. The sky is a copper blue. We are all silent, slowed, except where the sun touches, where people glide quickly towards the shadows.

Jun 18, 2017

At last, reasonable coffee on Kings Road. Hagen, opposite the Curzon. They’re not up to speed quite yet - and everything’s £2. If they keep it real, I’ll be back. Don’t tell me about any other places on Kings Road for coffee. They all suck and need to know it.

Jun 17, 2017

“At the time of writing, the general election has not yet occurred. No doubt, … everybody will be able to look back and see that the result was inevitable.” Clive James

Jun 14, 2017

Every time I hear the opening to Laurie Anderson’s “O Superman”, I think I’m going to fast forward. I never do. I never do.

“… even where science isn’t needed.” John Roderick

Jun 12, 2017

This year I didn’t go to the book fair at Olympia, in London. I’ve been before - and it’s very interesting - but I find it quite different from most book fairs I’ve been to. It’s more of an exhibition and trade show. I’m looking for somewhere I can pick up stuff for under £10.

Jun 7, 2017

Every little seemingly unannounced change on Flickr makes me nervous. Viewing a photo from the Camera Roll is still alpha. “Profiles got a makeover” - and that’s also marked as alpha. Surely you’d build confidence with the basic features, not by adding this sort of stuff.

Jun 2, 2017

Wouldn’t it be great if Apple made a Siri speaker which wrapped an Airport Express - or even a Time Machine drive …

May 31, 2017

I can think of lots of things I’d like to see change and improve on MacOS. The idea that it’s “stable and feature complete” sounds nuts to me. For goodness sake, just look at the thing! There’s no perfect OS. And the current MacOS is nowhere near perfect.

May 29, 2017

When I do a Google search for “Barbican”, I get “Showtimes at Barbican Centre”, listed. The Barbican’s own website isn’t that clear. When I do a Google search for “BFI”, I get “Showtimes at BFI Southbank”, listed. The BFI’s website still has a modal popup and a carousel. 2017.

David Giles Conservation Mounter of Western Art on Paper at the British Museum writes on the skills and delicacies of preparing material for exhibition. I balked at the Beadlesque title, but who thinks of such trivial matters.

May 28, 2017

I’ve come on holiday by mistake. Too much of a march around town, almost too much. The heat never quite broke. The rain faltered down, tropical. London is damp fronds, steamed and smeared. Bad coffee, rescued by better tea. And perhaps tomorrow will be mild, or fair, lighter?

May 28, 2017

Sunday mornings seem to be an odd peak of landings into Heathrow. If I weren’t myself, I should be able to pick out what bird it was that sung that song - and so suddenly fell silent. Voices in the trees up towards the railway line. Distant traffic.

A photo of Brockwell from the air, by Jenny Brown on Flickr. You can make out the lido, opened 1937, closed 1990, re-opened 1994, Grade II listed 2003. The Modern Movement Design Fair is held there too, usually in May.
